title: Knights stay selfish
text:
Knights stay selfish Jesus Jimenez , jjimenez@richmond.gannett.com 9:07 p.m. EDT October 13, 2015 Northeastern's Connor Bray runs against Lincoln during a football game Friday, Oct. 9, 2015 in Cambridge City. (Photo: Palladium-Item Joshua Smith, Palladium-Item Joshua Smith) 3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Northeastern's football team has been in this position before, and the Knights have come through — a 6-0 record in the Tri-Eastern Conference and an opportunity to complete a 7-0 run. 
Northeastern wrapped up a share of a third straight TEC championship with Friday's 38-0 shutout victory over Lincoln, but the Knights are staying selfish. 
"I'll be honest with you, it's been great to clinch tonight, but this team doesn't want to stop there," Northeastern coach Mike Roeder said. "I think that next week is the game they want to win and they don't want to share it." 
Union City visits looking to play spoiler, and Winchester is certainly not looking past Centerville, winless or not, as the Falcons keep their hopes of a title share alive. 
The TEC champion Knights look for their second straight 7-0 run. 
“We just got to practice hard like we did (last) week," Northeastern junior Dakota Green said. "We practiced hard, because we knew this team was going to be tough and this team we’re getting ready to play is going to be really tough, so we’ve got to practice just as hard.” 
The Knights get a Union City team that improved as the season's progressed. 
The Indians are 4-4 under first-year coach Mike Thompson and have a similar offense to Northeastern's. 
“He runs a hybrid Wing-T," Roeder said of Thompson. "He’s a double wing type of guy and a lot of things that we saw on film against Lincoln are some of the things we ran (last Friday). 
"We’re very similar offensively, I would expect it’ll be a game of whoever misses an assignment, because we both know what each other does, and they have one of my former defensive coordinators as an assistant there, so there shouldn’t be many surprises, I wouldn’t think.” 
Northeastern has outscored TEC opponents 162-49 while Union City has been outscored 178-136. 
The Knights' defense allows 8.2 points per TEC opponent, a year after allowing about 10.9 per league game. 
Jake Slinker and Alec Hughes are tied for second in the TEC with four interceptions each while Harrison Rice and Gunnar Adams each have six sacks, Green has four and Chace Mosley has three. 
“Defense is where we’ve started and continued to start every game," Roeder said. "... (W)e kind of take pride in that and we challenged them. They have responded every time this year.” 
Around the area, Winchester visits Centerville, Hagerstown visits Lincoln, Union County is at Tri, Eaton is at Bellbrook and National Trail at Bethel. 
A Winchester win, paired with a Northeastern loss, could force a tie for the second time in three years. 
“Once we lost control of our own destiny, it’s one of those things you don’t even talk about,” Winchester coach Mike Jones said. “It’s been a motivating factor, it’s made us get better and I think in the long run we’re probably a better team because of it. ... We know it’s senior night for Centerville.” 
TEC STANDINGS 
Northeastern 6-0 TEC, 6-2 overall 
Winchester 5-1, 6-2
